results.title: The Craic
results.creator_credit: Ted Emery, Jimeoin McKeown, Marc Gracie, David Foster, Australian Film Commission, Geffer Notice, Foster Gracie and Crack Pty Ltd
results.brief_description: Craic is Irish slang for a laugh or a good time, which is what this comedy about two Irishmen on the run in Australia is all about. Fergus (Jimeoin) and his best friend Wesley (Alan McKee) are living in Belfast when they incur the wrath of violent IRA leader, Colin (Robert Morgan). Since Ireland no longer seems like a safe place to stay, they head for Sydney, where they manage to find work despite not having the necessary work permits. Fergus gets a chance to appear on TVs “The Dating Game” and wins a vacation to Queensland. However immigration authorities become aware of the friends’ illegal status and Wesley tracks down Fergus, just in time to meet up with Colin who has come to Australia as part of the witness protection program. Thus a mad chase ensues as Fergus and Wesley head for the outback with immigration agents, secret service men and IRA renegades hot on their trail.

results.title: The Count
results.creator_credit: Lone Star Corporation, Kodascope Libraries and Charles Chaplin
results.brief_description: A series of slapstick antics take place during a formal dinner at Miss Moneybags between Charlie in the kitchen, his ex-boss the tailor who is prentending to be a count and the cook who is the centre of attraction for one and all including Charlie. The antics reach a crescendo when the real count turns up. Cast includes Charles Chaplin, Eric Campbell, Edna Purviance, Frank J. Coleman, Charlotte Mineau. Silent film with English intertitles.

results.title: The Conversation
results.creator_credit: Francis Ford Coppola, Paramount Pictures and Zoetrope Studios
results.brief_description: Gene Hackman plays Harry Caul, an expert surveillance man, who during a routine wire-tapping job hears snatches of conversation which make him believe a young couple is in danger. The more Harry tries to discover the secret surrounding the couple, the more he descends into a nightmare of secrecy, betrayal and murder, all taking place amidst a world of moral ambivalence. Influenced by the Watergate scandals of the early 1970’s, “The Conversation” is a tense and excellently edited suspense thriller. It is also Coppola’s most anguished and personal film.

results.title: The Commitments
results.creator_credit: Allan Parker, Lynda Myles, Roger Randall-Cutler and Sovereign Pictures
results.brief_description: Alan Parker’s tale of an Irish working class band’s odyssey is a strident belt-you-in-the-mouth delight. On a mission to bring soul to Dublin plus fame and fortune for himself, Jimmy Rabbitte transforms a motley bunch of misfits and raw talent into ‘the hardest working band in the world’, THE COMMITMENTS, billing them as the ‘saviours of Soul’. Based on the cult novel by Roddy Doyle and set to a scorching soul soundtrack. This film pulsates with raw energy, colourful dialogue, working class struggles and big time dreams - it’s a knockout.

results.title: The Comancheros (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Michael Curtiz, George Sherman and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A member of the legendary Texas Rangers works undercover to foil a notorious gang of outlaws in this top-notch Western. John Wayne stars as the two-fisted Ranger heading a cast that includes Stuart Whitman and Lee Marvin. The last film directed by Michael Curtiz “The Comancheros” is a lively, riotous Western with some exciting action sequences. Based on the novel by Paul I. Wellman.

results.title: The Cocoanuts
results.creator_credit: Robert Florey, Joseph Santley, Walter Wanger, James R. Cowan, Monta Bell and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Another hilarious film starring Groucho, Harpo, Zeppo and Chico Marx, ‘Cocoanuts’ is one of the early talkie films and the Marx Brother’s first film. Set in Miami, Groucho Marx plays Hotel Manager, Mr Hammer, struggling to keep his establishment from going under. Hammer’s only paying guest is Mrs Potter (Margaret Dumont), whose daughter Polly (Mary Eaton) is in love with aspiring architect, Bob (Oscar Shaw). Mrs Potter would prefer that Polly marry the respectable Harvey Yates (Cyril Ring); little does she know that he is a jewel thief. Throughout this basic story the four Marx brothers create havoc in their usual slapstick manner, with hilarious results.

results.title: The Change at Groote
results.creator_credit: Stefan Sargent, Richard Mason and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Designed to show how the aboriginal people of Groote Eylandt in the Gulf of Carpentaria are adjusting to the new life brought about by the discovery on their lands of vast manganese deposits which are now being mined by Broken Hill Proprietary. Made as a fragmented collage of images and sounds, it is intended to produce a direct emotional response, and suggest the confused values of the aboriginals undergoing a social and cultural revolution.

results.title: The Brood
results.creator_credit: David Cronenberg, Claude Heroux, Mutual Productions and Elgin International Films
results.brief_description: Director David Cronenberg considers this film his most personal one to date. A bold admission considering the disturbing material and particularly bitter look at marital break ups and the psychological effects that are passed down the generations. Cronenberg treats his themes of family dysfunction with his usual trade marks of experimental therapies run amuck and bodies rebelling against their hosts in the most visceral and graphic ways. Oliver Reed plays Doctor Hal Raglan, the mind behind an unconventional and radical institute which deals specifically with the physical effects of rage on the human body. One of his star pupils, the deranged Nola (Samantha Eggar), begins to use this very strange form of anger management to get back at her ex-husband (Art Hindle) who has custody of their five year old daughter. Cast also includes Cindy Hinds, Henry Beckman, Nuala Fitzgerald.

results.title: The Bride of Frankenstein
results.creator_credit: James Whale, Carl Laemmle and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Using the device of a prologue in which Mary Shelley takes up her story, the monster and Frankenstein were resurrected at Universal’s behest. Although the threads of continuity in the plot are explicit, in tone this is not really a sequel but a macabre comedy, an excursion into the fantastic which hovers between expressionism and surrealism. Karloff’s monster is the only sympathetic character. The mad scientist, Dr. Pretorius, seems to take over the evil presumptions of Frankenstein. As originally conceived, the heart of Frankenstein’s bride, Elizabeth, was to have been implanted in the she-monster. This makes more sense of the title and the she-monster’s behaviour. Suggested by the original story written in 1816 by Mary Wollstonecroft Shelley. Also includes a comprehensive documentary detailing various aspects of the production, including music, make-up, and behind-the-scenes information.

results.title: The Boy Kumasenu
results.creator_credit: Sean Graham, John Hollingsworth and Gold Coast Film Unit
results.brief_description: Dramatised documentary of a young African boy, Kumasenu, making his way unaided from the tribal world into the twentieth century. He has known no life other than that of a quiet fishing village. Wrongly accused of bringing bad luck to his people he becomes an outcast and an easy prey to the temptations of the city life of which his flash friend Agboh thinks so highly. Until helped by new friends, life for him is bewildering and dangerous.
